description: Numbers that are not the sum of two abundant numbers (not necessarily distinct).
references: The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers, David Wells, entry 20161.
Lure of the Integers, Joe Roberts, integer 20161.
Parkin, Thomas R.; Lander, Leon J.; Abundant numbers, Aerospace Corporation, Los Angeles, 1964, 119 unnumbered pages. Copy deposited in UMT file.
Pirani, F. A. E.; Problems For Solution "E903", The American Mathematical Monthly, Vol. 57, No. 2, (February 1950), p. 113.
Pirani, F. A. E.; Moser, Leo; Selfridge, John; E903, The American Mathematical Monthly, Vol. 57, No. 8. (October 1950), pp. 561-562.
Review of "Abundant Numbers by Thomas R. Parkin and Leon J. Lander", Mathematics of Computation, Vol. 19, No. 90. (April 1965), p. 334.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1456 (complete sequence)
example: 12 is abundant, so 24=12+12 is not a term.
author: _Jud McCranie_
